texts.shortText: Doris radiata Gmelin, 1791: unaccepted (synonym); Glaucus distichoicus A. d'Orbigny, 1836: unaccepted; Glaucus flagellum Blumenbach, 1803: unaccepted (synonym); Glaucus hexapterigius Cuvier, 1805: unaccepted (synonym); Glaucus lineatus Reinhardt & Bergh, 1861: unaccepted > nomen nudum; Glaucus lineatus Reinhardt & Bergh, 1864: unaccepted; Glaucus longicirrhus Reinhardt & Bergh, 1861: unaccepted > nomen nudum; Glaucus longicirrhus Reinhardt & Bergh, 1864: unaccepted.

A small to medium-sized blue- and silver-bodied aeolid with distinctive blue-tipped cerata arranged in spreading rays. The head is dark bright blue with lateral silver stripes. The oral tentacles and rhinophores are short, smooth and blue-tipped. The notum is silver. The cerata extend from three translucent appendages with central blue streaks. The cerata have silver bands or central silver stripes. The foot has two dark blue stripes, and is transparent silver at the centre and sides. The posterior end of the foot is slender, tapered, and dark blue.

Global: Circumtropical and subtropical.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to Mozambique, pelagic on the surface.

This species lives in the open ocean and is only rarely seen inshore. The animals are sometimes washed inshore and onto the beach after strong onshore winds. They float upside down on the surface of the ocean and maintain buoyancy by gulping air into their stomachs.

This species feeds on various species of pelagic colonial hydroids such as the Bluebottles, Physalia spp., the Blue buttons, Porpita spp., and the By-the-wind sailors, Velella spp. They use the highly toxic stinging cells of their prey for their own defenses. Though some studies suggest that these sequestered stinging cells cannot harm humans, it is probably safest to avoid touching these animals with bare skin.
This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon consists of extended densely coiled blue spiralling strings.

The species can be confused with the Indo-Pacific sea swallow, Glaucus marginatus, as well as other species in that complex, but is distinguished by the single layer of cerata on each lateral appendage.
